_chemical.ChemicalName: Hydrogen fluoride/Hydrofluoric acid (conc 50% or greater) [Hydrofluoric acid]

_accidents.ED_Other: Only 5 gals (34 lbs) of diesel got on soil, rest was contained on concrete

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CATLETTSBURG REFINING, LLC
Risk Management Program Plan
May 2009


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for its employees, the public, and the environment.  Catlettsburg Refining,LLCA?s policy is to conduct activities so as to protect and promote the health and safety of its employees, customers, and others who may be affected by these activities, and to limit adverse effects on the physical environment in which its ctivities are carried out. As part of this policy, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has established systems to help ensure safe operation of the processes at this facility.  One part of these systems is a Risk Management Program (RMP)that helps manage the risks at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC and that complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection AgencyA?s (EPAA?s) rule 40 CFR part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs (the RMP rule).  One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to resubmit its 
risk management plan (RMPlan) describing the Risk Management Program at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC every five (5) years.  This document is intended to satisfy the RMPlan executive summary requirements of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of the risk management program at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC.

1.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC is committed to the safety of its employees and the public, and to the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances.  Key to this commitment is the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances in and around the refinery.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC utilizes engineering controls, inspection programs, and detailed procedures as a means to prevent accidental releases.  In the event of a release, the refinery has a well trained emergency response team to contain, mitigate, monitor, and

stop the release.  The refinery has fully staffed and trained emergency response teams for fire fighting (Fire and Rescue Squad), medical emergencies, oil spill response (Oil Spill Response Team), and ambient air monitoring (Air Monitoring Team).  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC evaluates each situation, responds based on the particular circumstances, and if necessary, requests assistance from outside emergency responders, including local fire departments, in controlling and containing the release and to prevent and/or reduce the consequences of the release.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC, the local emergency planning committees (LEPCs), and the fire department have also established a system for warning the community if an accident occurs that could threaten the community.

The Catlettsburg Refining, LLC Manager has overall responsibility for the development and implementation of the risk management program at the facility.  However, the specific responsibilities for certain aspects of that program have been delegated by the Manager to other personnel who report either directly, or through other management personnel, to the Manager.  Those relationships are depicted on the facility organization chart.  Specific responsibility for the implementation of the Process Safety Management (PSM), the RMP hazard assessment and risk management plan and accident prevention program has been delegated to the Environmental, Safety and Security Manager.  The facility emergency response program, including compliance with the RMP aspects of that effort, is also the responsibility of the Environmental, Safety and Security Manager.  In keeping with our policy that safe operation is part of everyoneA?s job, many other refinery personnel are also involved in RMP activities on an ongoing basis.

2.    Regulated Substances

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC is a full range refinery and petroleum products facility located in Catlettsburg, Kentucky.  We use crude oil as our feed material and make a variety of

petroleum-based products, including gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, asphalt, specialty chemicals, and liquefied petroleum gases such as propane and butane.  Many of these products are flammable substances that the EPA has specifically listed in the RMP rule and are present in our process units above the EPA threshold quantity of 10,000 lb.  In total, we have 29 process units that are covered by the RMP rule because of their flammable process materials.  These units are listed in the RMP data included with this summary.
 
Catlettsburg Refining, LLC handles one toxic substance, hydrofluoric acid (HF), in sufficient quantity to be covered by the RMP rule.  It is used to make high quality gasoline components.

Chlorine is used at the facility to treat cooling water systems.  However, it is supplied in 1-ton cylinders (DOT approved) and is stored and used in quantities that are below the RMP threshold.

3.    Accidental Release Prevention Program

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC.  The processes at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC that are regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  The OSHA PSM requirements are very similar to the EPA RMP requirements for refineries, therefore this summary addresses each of the OSHA PSM elements.  The PSM program at this facility has been extended by Catlettsburg Refining, LLC, where necessary, to satisfy EPAA?s Program Level 3 accident prevention program requirements.

3.1     Employee Participation

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.  Examples of employee participation range from development of PSM/RMP program procedures and revisions, updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as members of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA

) team, incident investigation team, and compliance audit teams.  Employees have access to all information created as part of Catlettsburg Refining, LLC accident prevention program.  Specific ways that employees are involved in the accident prevention program are documented in an employee participation plan that is maintained at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC and addresses each accident prevention program element.  In addition, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has a number of initiatives under way that address process safety and employee safety issues.  These initiatives include a Behavior Based Safety program, a Joint Union Management Team, the Safety Action Process, and the Responsible CareA? Program to promote both process and personal safety. The teams typically have members from various areas of the plant, including operations, maintenance, engineering, and plant management.

3.2     Process Safety Information

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC keeps a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information. Specific departments within Catlettsburg Refining, LLC are assigned responsibility for maintaining up-to-date process safety information.   These documents can be retrieved electronically from  control rooms for any process unit in the Emergency Operations Center (EOC) room.

Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDSs). This information is supplemented by documents that specifically address known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals.  For specific process areas, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperatur

e, level, composition) in a Not-To-Exceed Limits Document.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC ensures that the process is maintained within these limits by using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrumentation systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems). 

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc. This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.

3.3     Process Hazard Analysis

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has a comprehensive PHA program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage those hazards.

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC primarily uses the Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations.  HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques available.  Checklists are utilized to evaluate Human Factors and Facility Siting.  The analyses are conducted using a team of people who have operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise and a trained team leader. This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes recommendations for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary. 

The PHA team recommendations are forwarded to local management for re

solution. Implementation of safety improvements in response to PHA findings is based on a relative risk ranking assigned by the PHA team.  They ensure that potential accident scenarios assigned the highest risk receive prompt attention.  All approved safety improvements being implemented in response to PHA team recommendations are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each recommendation is documented and retained.

To help ensure that the controls put in place originally and those added as a result of the HAZOP do not eventually deviate significantly from the original safety intent, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC periodically updates and revalidates the PHA results.  These periodic reviews are conducted at least every 5 years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating.  Offsite effects have been considered in all PHAs completed after August 1996.  The results and recommendations from these updates are documented and retained.  Once again, the team findings are forwarded to management for consideration, and the final resolution of the  recommendations is documented and retained.

3.4     Operating Procedures

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC maintains written procedures that address various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) temporary operations, (4) emergency shutdown, (5) normal shutdown, and (6) initial startup of a new process.  These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators.  Procedures are certified annually as current and accurate.  Procedures are maintained current by revising them as necessary to reflect changes made to the process.  In addition, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC operating procedures provide guidance on how to respond to events that result in exceeding safe operating limits for specific process or equipment parameters.  The written operating procedures are readily availabl

e to operators in each of the control rooms for the process units and for other personnel to use as necessary to safely perform their job tasks on a computer based system.

3.5     Training

To complement the written procedures for process operations, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has implemented a company training program for all employees involved in operating a process.  New employees receive basic training in Catlettsburg Refining, LLC operations if they are not already familiar with such operations.  After successfully completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks.  After operators demonstrate (e.g., through tests and skills demonstration) having adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks in a safe manner on their own, they can work independently. In addition, all operators periodically receive refresher training on the operating procedures to ensure that their skills and knowledge are maintained.  This refresher training is conducted at least every 3 years.  All of this training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify that the operator understood the training.

3.6     Contractors

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC uses contractors to supplement its work force during periods of increased maintenance or construction activities.  Because some contractors work on or near process equipment, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has procedures in place to ensure that contractors (1) perform their work in a safe manner, (2) have the appropriate knowledge and skills, (3) are aware of the hazards in their workplace, (4) understand what they should do in the event of an emergency, (5) understand and follow site safety rules, and (6) inform Catlettsburg Refining, LLC personnel of any hazards that they find during their work. This is accomplished by providing contractors with access to (1) a process overview, (2) information about safety and health hazards, (3) emergency response plan r

equirements, (4) safe work practices, and (5) a work permit process (i.e., for hot work, confined space, etc.) prior to their beginning work.  In addition, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC evaluates contractor safety programs and performance during the selection of a contractor.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their safety obligations.  In 2008, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC had its safest year ever with an OSHA Recordable Rate of 0.25. This is a significant achievement, given the amount of work performed during the year. 

3.7     Pre-Startup Safety Reviews

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC conducts a pre-startup safety review for any new facility or facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the review is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and the equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  The review team uses checklists to verify all aspects of readiness.  A review involves field verification of the construction and serves a quality assurance function by requiring verification that accident prevention program 
requirements are properly implemented. 

3.8     Mechanical Integrity

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The basic aspects of this program include: (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures, (3) performing inspections and tests, (4) correcting identified deficiencies, and (5) applying quality assurance measures.  In combination, these activities form a system that maint

ains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.

Maintenance personnel receive training on (1) an overview of the processes on which they will be working, (2) safety and health hazards, (3) applicable maintenance procedures, (4) emergency response plans, and (5) applicable safe work practices to help ensure that they can perform their job in a safe manner.  Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels).  If a deficiency is identified, employees will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service, or a management of change team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.

Another integral part of the mechanical integrity program is quality assurance.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.  This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made. 

3.9     Safe Work Practices

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has long-standing safe work practices in place to help ensure worker and process safety.  Examples of these include (1) control of the entry/presence/exit of support personnel into the refinery and process areas and units, (2) a lockout/tagout procedure to ensure isolation and de-energization of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance, (3) a procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened, (4) a hot work permit and procedure to control welding and other spark-producing activities, and (5) a permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined sp

ace.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.  Revisions to safe work practices are made periodically as needed and workers are informed of and/or trained on the revised procedures.

3.10     Management of Change

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.  Changes are reviewed to (1) ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards and (2) verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.  Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, are updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided with any necessary training on the change.  Changes are tracked electronically (by the Knowledge Management System) and signoffs are documented and retained.  Each change has a pre-startup safety review done on it prior to placing the change in service.  

3.11     Incident Investigation

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or process related personnel injury.  The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.  The investigation team documents its findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards these results to Catlettsburg Refining, LLC management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation teamA?s findings and

recommendations are tracked (using the Knowledge Management System) until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least 5 years so that the reports can be reviewed during future PHAs and PHA revalidations. 

3.12     Compliance Audits

To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC periodically conducts audits to determine if procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented. Compliance audits are conducted at least every 3 years by a third party.  Both hourly and management personnel participate during the audit.  The audit team develops findings that are forwarded to Catlettsburg Refining, LLC management for resolution.  Corrective actions taken in response to the audit teamA?s findings are tracked until they are complete.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.

In 2008, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC underwent an OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) National Emphasis Program (NEP) Audit and no fines were incurred.  The refinery also underwent a Responsible CareA? Certification Audit and was certified as a Responsible Care A? facility.

4    Chemical-specific Prevention Steps

The processes at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC use chemicals that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation. The accident prevention program previously summarized is applied to all processes at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC. Collectively, these prevention program activities help reduce the likelihood of accidental releases occurring as a result of equipment failures or human errors involving toxic and/or flammable substances.

In addition to the accident prevention program activities, Catlettsburg Refining, LLC h

as safety features on many units to help (1) contain/control a release, (2) quickly detect a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various processes:

4.1  Release Detection

*  Chemical-specific detectors with alarms in selected areas including toxic chemical detectors in the Alkylation Unit and the Sulfur Recovery Units 

*  Closed circuit TV monitors in each of the control rooms including the Alkylation Unit

*  Air Monitoring Team

4.2  Release Containment/Control

*  Process relief valves that discharge to a flare to capture and incinerate process materials to prevent overpressure damage to equipment

*  Scrubbers to neutralize chemical releases such as the fuel gas scrubbers to remove hydrogen sulfide 

*  Manual and automatic valves to permit isolation of the process

*  Automated shutdown systems for specific process parameters (e.g., high level, high temperature)

*  De-inventory system for Alkylation unit 

*  Curbing or diking to contain liquid releases

*  Redundant equipment and instrumentation where needed (e.g., uninterruptible power supply for process control system, redundant firewater pumps, etc)

*  Release mitigation system for the Alkylation unit

*  Fire suppression and extinguishing systems throughout the refinery (e.g., at the solvent loading rack, propane bullets, and the FCC unit)

*  Trained emergency response personnel including approximately 45 trained Fire and Rescue Squad members

*  Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)

*  Several blast-resistant control buildings to help protect shutdown control systems and personnel

Since the last RMP submission, Catlettsburg Refining has permanently shutdown seven RMP covered process units.  They were the 1) No. 2 Crude Unit, 2) the Pitch Unit, 3) the G-Oil Unit, 4) the MEK Unit, 5) the Solvent Pretreater Unit, 6) the Solvent Hydrotreating Unit, and 7) the Aliphatics Unit.

5    Five-year Accident History

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC maintains a 5-year accident history that fulfills the requirements of the RMP rule. This history indicates a good record of accidental release prevention over the past 5 years.  No release of a regulated substance has occurred from Catlettsburg Refining, LLC within the last 5 years that has resulted in offsite consequences. However, there have been two incidents at the facility which resulted in onsite consequences.  We investigate every incident very carefully to determine ways to prevent similar incidents from occurring. The following table is a summary of the incidents at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC within the past 5 years which resulted in onsite consequences:

                                              2004   2005   2006   2007   2008   2009
Number of RMP Events with Onsite Effects       0      0       0     0       2      0
Number of RMP Events with Offsite Effects      0      0       0     0       0      0
 

6    Emergency Response Program

The Catlettsburg Refining, LLC maintains a written emergency response plan to protect employee and public safety as well as the environment. The purpose of the emergency response plan is to minimize the impact on the refinery and surrounding areas in the event of an emergency situation.  The plan consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released.  The plan also addresses severe weather conditions.  The plan address all aspects of emergency response, including responsibilities of the Emergency Response Team, proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, refinery evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after the initiation of the response, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  In addition, the Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has

procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.  Employees receive training in these procedures to perform their specific emergency response duties. The emergency response program is reviewed and updated at least once a year.

The overall emergency response program for the Catlettsburg Refining, LLC is coordinated with the Boyd County, Kentucky LEPC/DES and Cabell/Wayne County, West Virginia LEPC and with offsite responders who would be called to support emergency response efforts if required. This coordination includes periodic meetings with the agencies, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives.  In addition, emergencies at Catlettsburg Refining, LLC are classified in one of three levels as specified by the Emergency Response plan.  Level One emergencies involve minor incidents limited to the work site.  Level Two emergencies involve incidents which will not have an offsite impact but will require the activation of the Incident Command system and the Emergency Response teams.  Level Three emergencies involve incidents which could have an offsite impact and require the Incident Commander to contact the local fire departments (911 centers) and make a recommendation for public action.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate LEPC/DES officials and emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  In addition to participating in periodic LEPC/DES meetings, the Catlettsburg Refining, LLC conducts periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC/DES and emergency response organizations, and the refinery provides refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated

substances in the refinery. The most recent drill was June 27, 2008.

7    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Catlettsburg Refining, LLC continually strives to improve the safety of its operations through periodic safety reviews, the incident investigation program, and a program soliciting safety suggestions from the employees.  Catlettsburg Refining, LLC resolves all findings from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the process.  The following types of changes are planned during the next 5 years:

*  Continue implementation of Safety Instrumented Systems (SIS) on critical pieces of equipment in covered units until completed.

*  Implementation of MarathonA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) Improvement Initiative

*  Continue converting Cooling Water chlorine treatment to bleach treatment method
